final_answer.precision_note: Limiting data are 3 s.f. (5.00 g, 84.0%, 44.0, 100.1); report mass to 3 s.f.

method: First find the mass of calcium carbonate present using the stated purity: m(CaCO3) = 5.00 g × 0.840 = 4.20 g. From the balanced equation CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, 1 mol CaCO3 produces 1 mol CO2. Convert from CaCO3 mass to CO2 mass using molar-mass ratios for the 1:1 mole relationship: m(CO2) = m(CaCO3) × Mr(CO2)/Mr(CaCO3) = 4.20 × (44.0/100.1) = 1.85 g (3 s.f.).
checks: Only 4.20 g of CaCO3 is available, so CO2 produced must be less than this; 1.85 g is reasonable.
Using moles: 4.20/100.1 ≈ 0.042 mol CaCO3, giving 0.042×44.0 ≈ 1.85 g CO2 (consistent).
